titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Petition regarding a lighthouse at Sands Point, New York 1977.641
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-18 21:45:14 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Petition regarding a lighthouse at Sands Point, New York
did.abstract: A 1792 petition to the United States Congress to build a lighthouse at Sands Point, Long Island, N.Y. for the safe passage of ships to New York City. The document is dated 1792 and its creator is unknown.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Petition regarding a lighthouse at Sands Point, New York, 1792, 1977.641, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A petition to the United States Congress to build a lighthouse at Sands Point, Long Island, N.Y. for the safe passage of ships to New York City. The document is dated 1792 and its creator is unknown.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
